title: The Art of the Academic Introduction
description: Crafting compelling introductions that situate your scholarly contribution

exercises.title: The CARS Model
exercises.instruction: Learn John Swales's 'Create A Research Space' model for introductions

strategies: Claim centrality: 'X is a fundamental aspect of...'
Make topic generalizations: 'Research in this area has shown...'
Review previous research: 'Studies by A, B, and C have examined...'
moves.purpose: Establish the importance and context of your topic

strategies: Indicating a gap: 'Little attention has been paid to...'
Question-raising: 'These findings raise the question of...'
Continuing a tradition: 'Building on this work, I examine...'
moves.purpose: Identify the specific gap or problem your work addresses

strategies: Indicating structure: 'The paper proceeds as follows...'
moves.purpose: State your contribution and preview your argument

exercises.title: Compelling Opening Strategies
exercises.instruction: Analyze different approaches to academic openings

strategies.name: The Provocation
strategies.example: We routinely speak of 'having' time as if it were a possession that could be accumulated or spent. This locution, I will argue, reveals a fundamental confusion at the heart of our relationship to temporality.

strategies.name: The Paradox
strategies.example: The more data we collect about human behavior, the less we seem to understand it. This paradox lies at the heart of contemporary social science.

strategies.name: The Historical Turn
strategies.example: In 1948, Claude Shannon published 'A Mathematical Theory of Communication.' This paper would transform not only information theory but our very conception of what information is.
strategies.effect: Grounds abstract issues in concrete moments

strategies.name: The Analytical Pivot
strategies.example: Much has been written about the causes of the 2008 financial crisis. Far less attention has been paid to the conceptual frameworks that made it thinkable in the first place.
strategies.effect: Acknowledges existing work while creating space for new approach

exercises.title: Positioning Your Thesis
exercises.instruction: Decide where and how to place your thesis for maximum effect

options.example: This paper argues that attention should be understood as an ethical practice, not merely an economic resource.

options.description: Build context before revealing your claim
options.when: Complex interventions, when readers need preparation
options.example: [After establishing the problem] Given these considerations, I propose a reconceptualization of attention as fundamentally ethical.

options.description: Allow the argument to emerge through analysis
options.caution: Risk of appearing unfocused; requires skilled execution

exercises.title: Analyzing Published Introductions
exercises.instruction: Read this introduction and identify the CARS moves
exercises.introduction: The concept of 'fake news' has become ubiquitous in public discourse since 2016. Scholars have examined its psychological appeal, its political instrumentalization, and its technological amplification through social media platforms. These studies have advanced our understanding of misinformation, but they share a common limitation: they treat 'truth' and 'falsity' as unproblematic categories. This paper draws on insights from speech act theory to complicate this binary, arguing that fake news functions less as false content than as a degraded discursive modeâ€”one that undermines the very possibility of meaningful public communication.

analysis.move1: First three sentences: establishes importance of topic and reviews existing research
analysis.move2: 'These studies have advanced... but share a common limitation': identifies gap
analysis.move3: 'This paper draws on... arguing that': announces contribution and thesis

exercises.task: Write an introduction for a paper on the ethics of artificial intelligence, using all three CARS moves
